images.figcaption: Plate 1a. Burrow of tularensis; Note that there is no large mound of earth.
Plate 1b. Mound of earth, larger than average, thrown from a main entrance to a burrow. Note the rodent’s tracks in the loose earth. (Ruler shown is one foot long.)
Plate 1c. Mound of earth at entrance to a burrow of tularensis beside a rock.
Plate 1d. Surface runways radiating from a subsidiary burrow of tularensis.

Plate 1e. Habitat of Dipodomys ingens and Dipodomys heermanni tularensis. Dipodomys ingens occupies the level area in the foreground and tularensis the hillsides in the background, the line of demarcation between the habitats of the two species being just below the rocky area near the base of the hills.
Plate 1f. A store of seed of Bromus rubens in the blind end of a branch of a main tunnel.
Plate 1g. Heads of wheat cut by tularensis. Note that a head in the lower center has been thrashed. Photograph by Joseph S. Dixon.
Plate 1h. A much used dust bowl. Note the tail mark in the loose earth. (Ruler shown is six inches long.)

images.alt: Four newborn Tulare Kangaroo Rat pups. The eyes are closed, the ears are just bumps, the tail is about a third the length of the body.
images.figcaption: Plate 2a. A liter of tularensis one hour after birth; × ½.

images.alt: A four day old Tulare Kangaroo Rat pup resting on its stomach. The front paws are stretched to in front of the nose, the ears are developing, and the large rear feet are noticeable. The tail is tucked under the body.

An eight day old Tulare Kangaroo Rat pup resting on its stomach. The dark fur is short but very noticeable. The ears are developing but still appear proportionally small relative to adults. The tail still appears short for the species, but the hind foot shown is very large, almost reaching to the elbow of the front arm.

A twelve day old Tulare Kangaroo Rat pup resting on its stomach. The ears still do not appear fully developed. The tail is stretched behind the rat out of the picture frame. Distinct toes on the wide rear foot are very visible.

A 16 day old Tulare Kangaroo Rat pup crouched on all fours. The long hind leg and large foot are very apparent, the ears look like they have properly developed, the tail is longer than the length of the body, the wiskers are very visible.

A 20 day old Tulare Kangaroo Rat pup standing on its hind legs but leaning forward. The shortness of the front arms relative to the rear legs is quite apparent. The tail is stretched behind the rat extends beyond the image frame.

A 56 day old juvenile Kangaroo Rat pup. The quality of the image is poor but it appears it is standing on all fours rather than just the hind feet. The tail is behind the rat and in the full image frame, it is quite long, appearing to be just over twice the body length. There is an obvious fray of fur at the end of the tail.

A mother Tulare Kangaroo Rat carrying one pup with a second pup in front of her. She is standing on her hind legs with the pup in her mouth, it appears she is using one of her front paws to help support the pup.
images.figcaption: Plate 2h. Mother kangaroo rat carrying her young

images.alt: Close-up of the mother with a pup in her mouth. One of the pup’s front paws is on the ground.
images.figcaption: Plate 2i. Mother kangaroo rat carrying her young
Plate 2j. Kangaroo rat suckling her eleven-day old young; note that the young are lying on their backs. Photographed from below through a glass plate.

images.alt: The column headers and first three rows of data from Table 5 as shown on a small-screen display. In the first column, the words ‘AGE’, ‘days’, and ‘birth’ are broken over multiple lines. In the second column, the word ‘grams’ is broken up over multiple lines, and the numeric data points are broken up at the decimal point over multiple lines
images.figcaption: Screenshot of Table 5 on a small-screen device

metadata.dc:title: Natural History of the Tulare Kangaroo Rat
metadata.dc:description: Journal of Mammalogy, Vol. 22, No. 2, pp. 117–148
metadata.dc:creator: Donald T. Tappe
metadata.schema:accessibilitySummary: This publication attempts to conform to WCAG 2.0 Level AA. Validation by an accessibility expert has not yet been done.
